posts.title: \noptions for getting into the city from NJ?
posts.body:
My husband and I drive to (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103454960', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC from our home in Maryland a couple of times a year, but we are tired of the hassle of driving and the expense of parking in the city. We were considering taking a DC-NYC bus for our next trip in November, but that adds quite a bit of travel time (to get to the DC pickup location from where we live). So we are now considering driving to someplace in NJ where we can leave our car for a couple of nights and take the train (NJ Transit or PATH) into the city. I know there is a train from Hamilton, which would be easy for us to get to from 95/295, but I don't know if there is overnight parking (or even if it is allowed, if there will be any spaces when we get there Saturday around noon). I was also told that there is a train at Princeton Junction and that we can leave our car at a friend's house, but I don't know if leaving from PJ is as convenient as Hamilton. Another friend suggested we could park overnight at Woodbridge Metropark and get into the city from there but didn't specify whether this is NJ Transit or something else. I'm also wondering if it would make sense to go to Weehawken to get the ferry, but that would probably involve more traffic hassles than going to Hamilton or Princeton Junction. I don't know how driving to Weehawken compares with driving to Woodbridge Metropark.



Can anyone who has used one or more of these options give me some feedback on the parking situation and relative ease of getting into NYC from there? Also, do we need to reserve train tickets from any of these places, or can we just buy them at the station when we arrive? Again, we will be arriving at the station probably around noon on Saturday, and we will be taking the train from NYC back to the NJ station Monday (Veterans Day) mid-afternoon.

answers.title:
1.

Re: options for getting into the city from NJ?
answers.body:
You could try the parking lot at the Journal Square PATH station-

https:/\xe2\x80\xa6journal-square 



Whatever you decide, Have Fun!

answers.title:
2.

Re: options for getting into the city from NJ?
answers.body:
So you have a place to park for free near (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103455534', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Princeton Junction? 

They're commuter trains so you can get tickets at time of travel. Info: https://www.njtransit.com/

answers.title:
3.

Re: options for getting into the city from NJ?
answers.body:
(ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103456332', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Hamilton not only has a huge garage, but it has an outdoor overflow lot. You can park for 2 weeks with no problem or actually longer if you notify them when you arrive. The parking is $12 per day. It is right off Exit 65B of 295. They never run out of space, especially not on a Saturday. Most people park there to go to work in New York City or the nearby suburbs of NYC.

https://www.njtransit.com/rg/rg_servlet.srv\xe2\x80\xa6

This is better and cheaper than Princeton Junction, and 10 miles closer to Maryland. It costs $17.25 per person, I believe to get to NYC. If older than 62, it's only $7.25 if i remember right. I use the NJ Transit app and buy my ticket online 10 minutes before the train arrives. You have to purchase it then activate it. Or you buy the tickets from a machine at the station. The ride takes 85 minutes to go 65 miles. If you parked in NYC you couldn't do it all that fast. If you parked in Jersey City, the traffic lights would make you miserable there. And weekend parking is at least $12 per day in Jersey City, if you use a parking app.

No, Hamilton is certainly convenient. You can get two tickets on one app. Let the spouse not driving get the two tickets ready to activate when you get to the platform.
Edited: yesterday, 09:29

answers.title:
4.

Re: options for getting into the city from NJ?
answers.body:
When parking at Metropark, taking the commuter NJ Transit would be much less expensive than Amtrak, which shares the rail lines. Amtrak will cost about $30 each well in advance while NJT is about $12pp. Trip on NJT takes about an hour. 

Parking on the weekend is easy and inexpensive (roughly $10/24 hours). There are 2 huge garages, largely underutilized on the weekend. 

Tickets for NJ Transit are purchased at the station. There are ticket kiosks, and if I remember correctly, a manned ticket booth. 



https://www.njtransit.com/rg/rg_servlet.srv\xe2\x80\xa6



https://m.njtransit.com/mo/mo_servlet.srv\xe2\x80\xa6

answers.title:
5.

Re: options for getting into the city from NJ?
answers.body: Look up (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103456368', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');OurBus and see that it goes from the Park and Ride Lot on Georgia Avenue near Olney near the ICC (MD-200) in the morning at 7:45 and returns at night leaving NYC at 4:30 and 8 PM, the later one arriving back before Midnight. I didn't believe it until someone told us about it. $20 or $25 each way. Go down Norbeck, turn left on Georgia, and left into the lot just after the eastbound 200 entrance. Free parking; safe neighborhood (since I live right there).

answers.title:
6.

Re: options for getting into the city from NJ?
answers.body:
(ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103456469', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Hamilton and Princeton Junction are on the same NJ Transit rail line (the Northeast Corridor line), so the same trains stop at both. The only exception that I know of is that PJ is served by Amtrak a few times per day, but you don't want to use Amtrak for this trip (too expensive and infrequent).



Hamilton is a few minutes farther from NYC but will require less driving. Parking at PJ is cheaper ($6/day), but there is no garage; you'll have to park in an open lot. Parking at PJ is managed by the West Windsor Parking Authority (the station is located in the town of West Windsor). For information on using their parking lots go to https:/\xe2\x80\xa6Daily-Parking.aspx



The main thing to know is that you must pay for parking in advance at one of several automated kiosks. 



At both stations, you can park for up to 14 days. PJ has fewer spaces than Hamilton, but availability won't be a problem if you're arriving on a Saturday. At both stations, you buy train tickets from a NJ Transit vending machine. As someone noted earlier, these are commuter trains that don't take reservations in advance. It is possible to buy your tickets on the train, but you will pay a penalty (I believe it's $5).

answers.title:
7.

Re: options for getting into the city from NJ?
answers.body:
Just realized that you said you have a free place to park in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103456512', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Princeton Junction, so my information about parking at the station is probably unnecessary. 



I also forgot to mention that your NJ Transit rail tickets will be slightly cheaper if you start at PJ because PJ is one stop closer to NYC than Hamilton (but you'll have to drive a few miles farther).

answers.title:
8.

Re: options for getting into the city from NJ?
answers.body: Wow, you have all given me great information--I really appreciate it. NorthofDC, the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103463257', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');OurBus Georgia Ave. stop would be very convenient, but I just checked Trip Advisor reviews and about half of them are terrible. So I would be nervous about trying that. I think driving to Hamilton or Princeton Junction to get the train may be the best idea. We are both over 62 so the tickets will be fairly inexpensive, at least partially offsetting the parking cost if we decide to go to Hamilton. However, it is not that much farther to go to PJ and parking would be free there (at my friend's house). My husband is the driver, so I will let him make the decision.

answers.title:
9.

Re: options for getting into the city from NJ?
answers.body:
All good advice here for the question you asked.



Just wondering if you also considered BWI rail station and Amtrak?



Would be a bit more expensive - but I think faster door to door and on a cleaner/nicer train (IMHO) that has room for luggage.



But, as noted, your original plan will work fine, and will save $s.

answers.title:
10.

Re: options for getting into the city from NJ?
answers.body: RayR, thanks for that suggestion. Amtrak was the first option we considered, but the tickets were quite expensive--would be worth it if we were staying for several days (which we often do), but on this trip we are only staying 2 nights. We will only have carry-on luggage, so hopefully that will not be a problem on NJ Transit, especially on Saturday going into the city. However, we will probably be leaving the city Monday 3-4 pm, which I assume will be fairly crowded. Do you know if there are overhead racks on the NJ Transit commuter trains? Or are they more like subway trains, without any place for luggage? Of course, even on subway trains a lot of people have bags (for example, to go to the airport).

posts.title: \nWhat can do I with a 6.5 JFK layover? Enough for Manhattan?

The domestic flight on another airline leaves 330pm. (One flight purchase/batch with with two airlines partnered w/ each other - but implying I need a separate check-in process.) Given the time I need leaving the airport, preparing for the second flight, storing my backpack in a locker if I so choose, etc -- is this enough time to see the city? Or would you guys recommend I just stay at the airport?

answers.title:
1.

Re: What can do I with a 6.5 JFK layover? Enough for Manhattan?
answers.body:
I think it depends on how long it takes you to get thru immigration and that\xe2\x80\x99s largely dependent on how many other planes arrive at the same time.



There are no lockers at (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103447881', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');JFK but there,s luggage storage in 3 terminals

For ideas for staying closer to the airport, look at the extreme right column on this page, second bullet down.

I'm going to say no. Assuming you land on time it will likely take 1-2 hours to clear customs/immigration. It sounds like you'll need to recheck luggage and go through security again so allow a couple hours for that.

Re: What can do I with a 6.5 JFK layover? Enough for Manhattan?
answers.body:
You could, if you have time, spend a couple of hours in Forest Hills, see the fancy houses, the extremely pleasant shopping district, I'd say it's the nicest (to me) part of (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103448793', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC to live in. There are good diners on Queens Blvd and many stores on Austin St, 71st Avenue, and Queens Blvd. 

You get there by taking the Airtrain to Jamaica, and the E train for 10 minutes to "71st Avenue-Forest Hills". You save nearly 2 hours of traveling around and have an especially nice in-NYC place to visit.

Also, if it's one ticket, I doubt that you will have to check your luggage or check in a second time; but you will have to go through security to get back to the gates, of course. You can ask when you check the luggage the first time. If it has your final airport listed on the attached routing card on your luggage, you are set. Of course, you have to get your luggage at Customs at JFK, then they take it back afterwards to put on the next plane. Or at least, that's the normal procedure when it is on one ticket.

posts.title: \nItinerary help - 2 adults 2 teenagers early Nov for 5 days
posts.body:
Hi All



Ive been reading through all the fantastic tips, suggestions and trip reports ahead of our (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103429802', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC trip in early Nov. We are a family from Ireland, 2 adults, 2 teenagers age 16 and 14. We will be coming from a very relaxing week in Foridas gulf coast so will not be jet lagged when we arrive. Myself and husband have been to NYC many times before but kids have not so we will be doing a lot of the usual tourist stuff. Kids have opted not to do the Met and ANMH but I think I can convince them to look into MoMa. The only thing I have reserved is SOL with crown access on Weds, all other things can be moved about weather dependent. 



Below is a rough itinerary that Ive cobbled together to make the most of our time and areas that I believe are geographically close. All suggestions. recommendations welcomed. - Thanks! :)





Mon 4th 

Arrive Grand Central Terminal (we are coming from Scarsdale as will be visiting friends) hope to look around while there although will have luggage with us? Checkin if possible to hotel just off Times Sq. Walk to Vessel (will book tickets in advance when 2 weeks out), then high line down Chelsea Market. 

Greenwich/ Washington park? not sure how long all this will take? Go back to Times Sq for night time?



Tues 5th (think this day could be interchangeable with Thurs)

Central park with hire bikes - maybe ice skating there too? St Pats cathedral, ToTR and maybe ice skating there? I read that free tickets to the 911 museum become available on Tuesdays around 4pm? I'm not sure if the kids would like this or not - will defo visit the memorial pools at some stage. 



Weds 6th. 

SOL tour at 11, banking on at least 3/4 hours for this with Ellis island tour too. Maybe we should visit Wall street and 911 after this as we will be down that way?



Thurs 7th 

Subway to Brooklyn, look around DUMBO and walk back. no evening plans, maybe MoMa? 



Fri 8th.

Shopping and other last minute stuff as we need to leave for airport about 4pm. 



Hoping to see a show, possibly Book of Mormon for all of us (if we can get cheap tix) or Mean girls for myself and daughter. Husband and son might like Concorde and Intrepid musuem? 

We will be doing some shopping on and off and will be around Macys and Herald Square at some stage. 



thanks for your input.



JJ

answers.title:
1.

Re: Itinerary help - 2 adults 2 teenagers early Nov for 5 days
answers.body:
You have a lot of outdoor activities planned. I would make sure to have "Plan B's" in case of rain.



I think the kids may be too young for the 9/11 Museum. It is an intense emotional experience for most adults, and for many requires some "down time" to walk, meditate, pray, visit a house of worship, etc. I would not plan a fancy meal or expensive outing (play, sports event, etc.) for afterward.



You may have to wait in line for the SOL for about an hour. I would arrive by 10 a.m. If you fully explore Lad Liberty and (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103429918', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Ellis Island, you might have "museum overload" if you go to 9/11 thereafter.

answers.title:
2.

Re: Itinerary help - 2 adults 2 teenagers early Nov for 5 days
answers.body:
I have to disagree with the advice re the 9/11 Museum. It is actually perfect for teens that age and if you are coming from overseas, by way of FL, it is an important learning/teaching experience that they may not get a chance to visit anytime soon. 



The 9/11 Museum is what it is. Absolutely no reason to not take teens because it is intense. Teens need to realize what type of world we lived in then and now.

answers.title:
3.

Re: Itinerary help - 2 adults 2 teenagers early Nov for 5 days
answers.body:
To avoid confusion, use the term (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103430470', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Greenwich Village or the Village for short. Greenwich is a city in Connecticut - close enough to cause confusion.

As for Book of Mormon, there are no cheap tickets to this show, It is not on discount. Mean Girls is on discount. Check Broadway Box, Playbill & TheaterMania for discounts.

answers.title:
4.

Re: Itinerary help - 2 adults 2 teenagers early Nov for 5 days
answers.body:
Thanks for all the quick replies,

Good idea re having a plan B of weather is bad. And yes I'm on the fence about 911, my son is a history buff and would be keen my daughter I'm not so sure about. Think we might wait and see. thanks for the tip about waiting in line for SOL and The village as opposed the somewhere in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103430836', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Connecticut ;)



Apart from that does the plan look doable? I'm afraid of overloading the days. 



thanks again



JJ

answers.title:
5.

Re: Itinerary help - 2 adults 2 teenagers early Nov for 5 days
answers.body:
Hi there, have you thought of the intrepid at all? Is was a massive hit with my 10 year old son (who\xe2\x80\x99s very mature for his age) and now at almost 15 he says that was one of his favourite things in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103431012', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC and the one he\xe2\x80\x99d do again and again. I thoroughly enjoyed it myself and learnt a whole lot as well as had fun especially squeezing into a submarine. 

It maybe an idea if it\xe2\x80\x99s a rainy day. We spent a good half a day there and had dinner in the canteen which was a hit with my son who is keen on history and aviation. 

One evening we went bowing in Times Square which was a lot of fun and a big hit with my son as it had photos of many many celebrities bowing there. X

answers.title:
6.

answers.body:
^

2 very cool suggestions.

answers.body:
Brill, some more great ideas, yes we are considering the Intrepid, kids were on an aircraft carrier in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103431618', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');San Diego but were very young and were on a submarine in San Francisco too but really liked it. Bowling in Times Sq sounds good too. 



thanks again!

Re: Itinerary help - 2 adults 2 teenagers early Nov for 5 days
answers.body: Hope you guys have a blast x

answers.title:

Re: Itinerary help - 2 adults 2 teenagers early Nov for 5 days
answers.body: I highly recommend the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103432694', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Tenement Museum in the Lower East Side. It's a museum of immigration to the US, and there are different tours you can take. Maybe you would be particularly interested in one focused on Irish immigrant. I did the Under One Roof tour about 3 families who successively lived in the same tenement and our guide really held my teens' interest.

answers.title:
10.

Re: Itinerary help - 2 adults 2 teenagers early Nov for 5 days
answers.body:
If you are interested in going to the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103434350', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Tenement Museum, I would purchase the tour tickets ahead of time. They sell out, so you can't just show up and join a tour (speaking from experience here).



If your daughter has doubts about the 9/11 Museum, I would not force her to go. I often say here, I started reading Holocaust survivor stories when I was 12, but I would not have been ready to visit Auschwitz or Bergen-Belsen. There are things there that cannot be unseen, once seen. Every person has a different level of sensitivity from the next. The Museum is built on the footprints of the buildings, the site of a mass murder. Some people must leave (they have many doors in case it's too much). Some people lose their appetite. Again, I would discuss it thoroughly with your kids and it just may be the case that she (and/or he) are not ready. There's enough sadness in the world. If they want to wait, I would allow them.

posts.title: \nManhatten Hotels
posts.body:
Hello,

I will be attending a conference in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103433939', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Lower Manhatten around 435 Hudson for 1 day, the next day we will be at 205 W. 39th St. 

I don't know my way around NY at all.



I wanted to ask if anyone has a recommendation for a reasonably priced hotel in the area. It doesn't have to be fancy, just clean and with a fitness center.



Thank you for any advice anyone may have.
Edited: 17 October 2019, 23:13

answers.title:
1.

Re: Manhatten Hotels
answers.body:
Is it just you or will you be sharing a room? What is your preferred nightly budget? Is it just one night? What are your dates? Hotel prices vary from day to day based on what is happening in town. 



Those 2 addresses are about 2 miles apart. Do you prefer to stay closer to one of those places? 



Help the hotel gurus help you by providing some details.
Edited: 17 October 2019, 23:17

answers.title:
2.

Re: Manhatten Hotels
answers.body:
Exact dates are important, too. A hotel that costs $210 one night can go for $350 another night.



The easiest way to get around (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103434165', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC is via subway. You could stay at a hotel near either of these two places and take a subway to the other; stay in the middle and take the subway to both; or stay near neither, if necessary, and take a subway to both.

answers.title:
3.

Re: Manhatten Hotels
answers.body:
205 West 39th St is right at (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103434549', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Times Square. If you want to be in the middle of the most touristy of touristy sections (and many people do) stay anywhere near the southern end of Times Square. The streets (as you can tell) are numbered. How about the Hampton Inn Times Square South? It's right there at your venue. And the downtown (a direction) #1 train goes right to the venue on Hudson St (you get off at the Houston Street Station. To go back to Times Square, you take an Uptown #1 train. 

When someone says they know nothing, I recommend looking at the grid-like map of their neighborhoods: You know how St. Louis has numbered streets and well-organize cross-streets downtown? NYC is similar just better with numbered avenues crossing the numbered streets.

Hudson Street area: \xe2\x80\xa6mta.info/maps/\xe2\x80\xa6M02_SoHo_TriBeCa_2015.pdf

39th St Times Square Area: \xe2\x80\xa6mta.info/maps/\xe2\x80\xa6M11_midtown_2015.pdf

posts.title: \nItinerary help for 1st timer
posts.body:
I need a little help figuring out how to group some of must-do's on what days, etc. This is our first time, it is my husband and I and our 9 year old daughter. We are flying in Sat morning, Dec. 21 at 9:30am, and fly back to (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103413685', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Charlotte on Tues, Dec. 24, at 11am. We are staying at the Hilton Garden Inn at Times Square, so pretty central to a lot of things, I think. We plan to walk everywhere, unless weather doesn't allow that. Then we will take the subway or taxi.



We already have tickets to the Rockettes Christmas Spectacular on Sun. night at 10pm. The other things that we really want to do are:



Top of the Rock

Central Park-just walk around, daughter wants to stop in at the Plaza hotel

Rockefeller Plaza tree and area

Store Christmas displays one night

Macy's Santa visit

DUMBO and walk back across the Brooklyn Bridge, preferably around sunset

New York Botanical Garden

American Museum of Natural History, if time

9/11 Memorial if time, but may do that on another visit



We are mainly trying to do the Christmas stuff, since we can only do that at this time of year, and do plan to hopefully visit again at a non-Christmas time. Any help arranging what to do on what days would be greatly appreciated. And any other recommendations for must see's at Christmas? Thanks!

answers.title:
1.

Re: Itinerary help for 1st timer
answers.body: Which airport are you using?

answers.title:
2.

Re: Itinerary help for 1st timer
answers.body:
shroog, you need to get a hold of a good tourist's map. It will make planning so much easier, because you'll see where the sights are in proximity to each other.

The one I like best is the Red Map of Manhattan neighborhoods:

https://redmaps.com/products/nyc-map\xe2\x80\xa6

This is a beautiful, color-coded, laminated map that you can spread out onto a table. The family can plan together.

The (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103413861', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');New York Botanical Garden is an outlier for such a short trip. It will take at least half a day. If you want to commit that much time, great. But you might want to think about it.

Walking over the Brooklyn Bridge can be *very* cold at that time of year. Winds whipping over the bridge can make 40 degrees feel like 20. The weather might be good, though. A few years ago it was a strange 65 degrees on Christmas, so anything can happen.

Note: Visits to Santa at Macy's must be reserved.



Is your nine-year old going to be awake for a show that starts so late? You can do all of these prior to the show -- they're nearby: 

Top of the Rock (entrance is half a block from Radio City)

Central Park-just walk around, daughter wants to stop in at the Plaza hotel

Rockefeller Plaza tree and area 

Store Christmas displays one night

answers.title:
3.

Re: Itinerary help for 1st timer
answers.body: We are flying into (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103414005', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');LGA, and will only have carry-ons, so plan to do the Q70 to the subway to the stop right near our hotel.

answers.title:
4.

Re: Itinerary help for 1st timer
answers.body:
Looks like most of your stuff is midtown so transportation shouldn't be an issue / walking s.b. fine.



for the other stuff - NYBG, 9-11 Memorial, you'll obviously need to take some form of transportation. And you do want to group geographically to minimize back-and-forth time, which I think is the point of your post. I like google maps on my phone, which has Subway, Bus, Walk, (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103414055', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Car options



maybe do some practice trips, while referencing MTA maps on desktop computer

https:/\xe2\x80\xa6subway_map_web_2.pdf



I think above should give you some orientation. The major outlier is NYBG but that comes up here from time to time, search here for info/directions, and of course their website should have directions.



the main thing I want to mention, hopefully the weather will be ok but if it gets bad (very cold with rain/snow), taxis/ubers etc can be hard to come by (I had uber call me once saying they couldn't make it) so give yourself an extra hour if the weather is bad and you're planning to take a cab/uber somewhere

answers.title:
5.

Re: Itinerary help for 1st timer
answers.body:
(ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103414123', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC is big and things are spread out. Some of your plans will be great for good long walks. Others will need transportation. Don't let your desire to walk end up skewing you to be focused primarily on things near midtown as it is really worthwhile to get into other neighborhoods. Otherwise you end up with too many images of skyscrapers and crowded sidewalks IMO. 



I'd also encourage you to mix Christmas activities with other things. While some of the Christmas things are unique, others aren't really THAT unique and it's good to balance in some of the fundamentally fantastic NYC things with some of the "special but maybe not world class fantastic" seasonal things.



For the short visit, I wonder if the Botanical Garden is really worth your time investment vs doing something else. Yes, there is a special train show but unless you have a very strong interest in trains as a hobby, do something else... even if it's not specifically about Christmastime.



Add to your Christmas activities the Winter Village at Bryant Park (near Times Square) There is ice skating and nice holiday market vendor stalls plus some food stalls. It can get very crowded so try to go at a less crowded time. Probably earlier in the day is less crowded than late.



Note that you will need to make reservations for Macy's santa. Keep an eye on Macy's Santaland for info about when timed tickets are released. https:/\xe2\x80\xa6



One more benefit of planning a few non-Christmas things is it can give you a break from crowds. You may really need that. If it gets overwhelming, plan to stroll around some quieter-but-interesting neighborhoods.

answers.title:
6.

Re: Itinerary help for 1st timer
answers.body:
Great info LizzieandIzzy! Yes, she will be fine staying up late. I hope. We are always up late on different vacations, and she has no problem, so hopefully that will be the same here. I specifically chose late because of I don't want to waste any daylight in a show, plus it's cheaper at that time. lol



How long does it take to do a nice stroll and see the sites, through (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103414139', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Central Park? I'm thinking we could spend all day Sunday doing that and checking out the Plaza, maybe some other must see's around, along with Rockefeller Plaza, some shopping, try and do TOTR at sunset, and then dinner and Rockettes. If that is all doable? Then, we still have Sat to do whatever, and all day Monday. Maybe Monday we could do 9/11 Memorial, DUMBO area, and walk across the bridge (weather permitting). And, Santa and store displays Mon night. I don't want to try to cram too much into the trip, because then I will miss too much of the moments, you know what I mean?

7.

answers.body: LarryD and Christnp2 -very good points! Thank you! I did forget about (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103414261', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Bryant Park and the Winter Village-I would like to hit that. And, walk by/through some landmarks. I think I may nix the New York Botanical Garden. My daughter and husband would love the train display, but they aren't really that into trains or anything, and I think it may not be worth it. Maybe we can hit the American Museum of Natural History instead-we all would enjoy that.

Re: Itinerary help for 1st timer
answers.body:
Here is some info. on getting to the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103416064', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');New York Botanical Garden. You could leave from Grand Central Terminal (42nd and Park Ave./Vanderbilt Ave.), taking a MetroNorth train. The directions say it's a 20-minute ride. Then you walk a bit to the entrance. It's not hard. The Garden is HUGE so you might want to focus on getting to the destination, if you'll do it.

https://www.nybg.org/visit/directions/

Tickets for the train show: When I went into the site for tickets, a pop-up came up with an offer for 30% off for early ticket buyers. *That* is a welcome good deal, because the tickets are expensive.

The theme this year is Central Park. CP will probably be very cold on your dates. It might be fun to visit the train show and get an idea of what you can see in CP, and then go later -- even on your next trip.

I think 9 is a perfect age for this. 

Okay, I admit I'm sounding a bit biased. I'm thinking about taking my 9-year old niece there this year. ;-)

Re: Itinerary help for 1st timer
answers.body:
Here is my suggested itinerary:



Day 1

Afternoon Tea at (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103455910', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Palm Court (Plaza Hotel)-it is pretty laid back (not rushed) but good. 

Rock Center Tree and decorations (maybe TOTR) A majority of the Best Decorations are on 5th Ave between Rock Center and the Plaza.

Rock Center Cafe is a good dinner option.

Day 2

Maybe do Santa this day since you have Rockettes at night, if you are up to it (and you get an early time for Santa) work in Central Park walk and possibly AMNH in the afternoon.



Day 3

After Breakfast you could take the E (Subway) Train downtown to the last stop (World Trade), The Foot Print Fountains are free, and The West FIeld Center and Brookfield Place Winter Garden are some high lights in the immediate surrounding area. If you want to lunch at OWO or Gigino Wagner Park there are views of the Statue of Liberty from either. After walk across Wall St and take the east river Ferry over to DUMBO. Maybe Jane's Carousel if it is open, or walk across Bridge. If it is too cold or you are too tired you can have dinner (a couple decent pizza options) and catch the East river ferry back to Manhattan and take the N or R subway liine from City Hall back uptown.



Note: That Palm Court also offers breakfast if you want to do that another day



Whatever you decide...



...Happy Planning & (most importantly) Have Fun!

If you can easily do 20- to 40 stairs, you can take the subway to see a show and to see Times Square. Otherwise you might use a bus, taxi, or car service.

The sights in NYC are quite spread out. Did you have anything else on your itinerary?

Sights are spread out in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103434381', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');New York City. Some are, like already stated, within walking distance of your hotel. You are also pretty close to Tribeca where you can find many good restaurants.



The good thing about staying in that area is that it is on the southern tip of Manhattan, where the island is narrower. This means you'll have many subway lines and stations nearby. You can easily reach Times Square, for shows, Upper West Side for American Museum of Natural History as well as Upper East side and the Met Museum without having to change a subway line. 



I haven't stayed at that particular hotel, but in hotels within walking distance several times. I find it easy to often get decent rates and since I use the subway system extensively when in town, I would gladly stay in the area again.



On my latest visti, I stayed a few minutes walk south of that hotel and had two nights at the theatre in the Times Square area, two ballets in Met Opera house as well as a concert in Madison Square Garden booked. So easy to get there and back to the hotel!

Most hotels in NYC are closer to the subway than that. 

So the Cruise Port is not really in a remote location; but compared to any hotel you choose, it can be thought of as more remote, a full half mile from the subway :^))) 

So you are thinking in less-dense-area terms; everything is convenient on the island of Manhattan, except for the crowds that sometimes slow you down. Don't worry; it's 4 avenues west of the 50th St station of the C train. Or you can take a taxi from your hotel or from the center of Times Square or anywhere. Staying "all the way" downtown is 5 miles from the Cruise Port, and almost everything famous is in those 5 miles.

answers.body:
I believe the Verrazzano closes at 7am, but you should check the race website. If you go the Uber route (which I agree with NYWhiz is going to be expensive!), you need to allow extra time for congestion (and to allow your driver to get back over the bridge after dropping you off). All in all, this doesn\xe2\x80\x99t strike me as a good plan. 



You don\xe2\x80\x99t mention which wave you\xe2\x80\x99re starting in, or whether you signed up for any of the official transportation options to the start. Hopefully you can still do do (I\xe2\x80\x99m not running this year, so I\xe2\x80\x99m not up to speed on the current deadlines). The preferred method is no longer the bus from midtown, but the ferry.



Especially if you\xe2\x80\x99re in one of the later waves, you should be able to spend the night in Merrick and take public transit to the start...but you really need to check the ferry schedule and the sign up procedures. You can find all this on the race website. 



Good luck, and have a great race!

We may do a broadway show but not totally sure. We aren\xe2\x80\x99t really into theatre, art, or music too much. We do like history, shopping, good food, and seeing the main attractions. Any advice on where to stay, the best way to go about seeing these sites, also any other advice I may be missing is great. Thanks again for any help.

Re: First trip to NY
answers.body:
We would be glad to help.



If you post your budget (including 15% tax), you can help us help you.



Congratulations!

answers.title:
2.

Re: First trip to NY
answers.body:
Easy answer: Stay anywhere you want that you can afford; no hotel is near everything, but every hotel is near something.

The way you get around is to take the subway or a taxi (or even walk) to go from one place to another. Everything you mentioned is in a 5 mile x1.5 mile rectangle. The place isn't all that big, but it's crowded so every neighborhood changes every half mile.

I personally would suggest staying near (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103417259', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Rockefeller Center or just south of Central Park; it's close to but not in Times Square (too noisy, too crowded with all those tourists), and where I mentioned looks prettier than many others and is near many famous things (but not all, remember that, nothing is).

But if the cost is too high, any place on the island of Manhattan south of 99th St is good, just not west of 10th Avenue (because of inconvenience and grittiness, not danger).

answers.title:
3.

Re: First trip to NY
answers.body:
To clarify, the reply 2 is for hotel recommendations. We also would like desired bedding configuration.

Get ahold of a guidebook (library/purchase) & use the maps to group your locations or perhaps purchase a paper tourism map. Since attractions are spread out all over, the most convenient/cost effective way of getting around is the subway.

For the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103417362', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Statue of Liberty, get your tickets ASAP from Statue Cruises if you want to set foot on Liberty Island. BTW, it's Times Square with an s (so that you don't get a spoof web site & so that Trip Advisor will link you to their site.

I recommend a guidebook so that you are finding the attractions that interest you - not anyone else. For example, I would recommend museums & theater but that's not your thing so I wouldn't want to give you advice as to what *you* should see.

and Absolutely NO OTHER site if you want to actually set foot on the island and see the Pedestal of the Statue from the inside. Crown tickets, which are hard to get, would not be a requirement for me.

If you go through another website, all they do is mark up and resell tickets from the site stated here.

Most of where you are going is on a grid pattern of streets, and there are 20 numbered streets to a mile, and 7 numbered avenues to a mile, so Rockefeller Center is at 50th and 5, the Empire State Building is at 34th and 5th (as examples). That's less than a mile.

posts.title: \nBest way from Newark Terminal B to Holiday Inn Times Square
posts.body:
What is the most efficient way to go from (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103468415', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Newark to Holiday Inn Times Square on 8th street. Re: Best way from Newark Terminal B to Holiday Inn Times Square
answers.body:
You need to have a good look at a map of (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103468509', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC since you are very confused. Your hotel is not o 8th St - which is far downtown - nowhere near Times Square. I assume you mean 8th Ave, which is a completely different thing.



That hotel is 585 8th Ave, which is between 38th and 39th St and on the west side. You need to understand how addresses work in NYC or you will just be wandering aimlessly and lose a lot of time. 



Taking the Airtrin to NJ Transit to Penn Station and then walking to your hotel (5/6 short blocks - about 1/4 mile) will cost $65 for all 5 of you. A car service or taxi for 5 will be more since you have to add tolls ($18) and the usual 20% tip for the driver to the basic fare quoted. Check with Uber or Dial 7 or Carmel what they will charge for a vehicle large enough for 5 people plus however much luggage you have.

Also for attractions like the Top of the Rock that have timed tickets, you don't get tickets with passes, you get vouchers & when you get to an attraction with timed tickets, you could find that the most convenient times are sold out. Also, I personally don't recommend any Hop On Hop Off bus ride in anything but comfortable weather as I was once taken on a HOHO in cool damp weather & sitting on top (where the best seats are) I froze.

Re: SoL Crown Access Children?
answers.body: I wouldn't take my kids up into the SOL Crown. Nothing spectacular. Stairs are too narrow inside. No windows only on the crown so it's quite suffocating inside. Once inside It's hard to back out, you have to continue to the top and go with the flow. The single line on the stairs goes only one way up and single line one way down. It's not that high that gives a "WOW" factor, unlike OWO, (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103450969', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Top of the Rock or ESB. The only thing that's worth it going up is to cross it off your bucket list and you can say " been there, done that!" Summer time is brutal to be inside the statue.

answers.title:
4.

Re: SoL Crown Access Children?
answers.body: How much under 10? I've done it twice though as an adult (and love it both times), but did take my 12 year old niece up one of those times. I would not want to do it on a hot summer's day (no AC). I'd say it depends on the kid

answers.title:
5.

Re: SoL Crown Access Children?
answers.body:
It's a spiral staircase that gets narrower and narrower as you get higher and higher up; you are inside the bronze robes. There is an UP spiral staircase that forms a helix with the DOWN Staircase. I also went when I was 12; I loved it; my father was exhausted. I tried with my wife in the 1970s; she made it up one turn of the steps and switched to the Down staircase and vowed never to try it again. If the kid is an explorer type, it might be great; will the two of you be able to take it, especially if it's 90 degrees outside? I'd wonder about that more.

Oh, and when you get to the top, you get to look out windows in the crown itself. Then you climb back down all those hundreds of spiral steps again. 

Some people read this and say: Cool! Some read it and say, Not ME!

Then again, I've gone down the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103451373', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Washington Monument, up and down the Baltimore version of the Washington Monument, the "Monument" in London, the Clock tower in Strasbourg, the Catwalk in the Duomo in Florence, If you are that type, have fun. My wife has done none of these.

answers.body: Yes, it's copper; as a kid everyone said it was bronze, because it was green, and there hadn't yet been writers who wrote in detail about any renovations. So we didn't know any better. And I haven't changed; just ask my wife: Ba da boom!

Re: SoL Crown Access Children?
answers.body:
Bronze is an alloy that is primarily copper so they oxidize in similar ways and once the patina is formed it can protect the underlying metal from further corrosion.

Bronze is more suited to investment castings (like most statues).because of the additives.

IIRC the exterior of the SOL is not load bearing and only a little thicker than a penny coin.

posts.title: \nNYC with 9 year old 11/29-12/1
posts.body: We are taking our daughter to (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103450453', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC Thanksgiving Weekend. We are planning to do the Rockettes and the American Girl Store. We would also like to go to the Statue of Liberty and my husband would like to go by the 9-11 Memorial. What is the best way to plan this and any other must sees for a 9 year old girl that we can squeeze in there?

answers.title:
1.

Re: NYC with 9 year old 11/29-12/1
answers.body:
You should book tickets for the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103450699', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Statue of Liberty immediately. The only official seller is www.statuecruises.com. Try to get the first tickets of the day. The later in the day you book, the longer the security line to get onto the ferry. Crown tickets are probably sold out, but you may find Pedestal tickets. The ticket includes a stop at Ellis Island, where thousands of immigrants came into the U.S. This excursion will take up at least 3- to 4 hours, not including transport to get to Battery Park for the ferry. It would be easy to view the 9/11 Memorial before or after.



Depending upon what time the Rockettes get out, you could visit the American Girl store right after. (I don't know where you could store your packages if you were to go before -- I don't think Radio City has package storage, but I could be wrong.) They are literally a half block from each other (AG is on 51st between 5th & 6th. Radio City is on 6th Ave. between 50th & 51st). You could also visit FAO Schwarz, which is now located in Rockefeller Center. Again, it's about a half block from Radio City. It's on Rockefeller Plaza, in the middle of 49th St. between 5th & 6th Aves. 

If the weather is good, you could also go up to Top of the Rock. It's also right there -- less than a half block from Radio City.



Where are you staying?

answers.title:
2.

Re: NYC with 9 year old 11/29-12/1
answers.body:
Actually going to the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103451020', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Statue of Liberty is a big time investment. Follow Lizzy's instructions for booking tickets if you are sure that you want to prioritize it for this short trip. Another option would be to do a sightseeing cruise for good views of Lady Liberty from the water, along with other views. This is a more relaxed and comfortable trip, but you don't get to be right on Liberty or Ellis Islands.



Is your daughter into science, nature and animals? (including dinosaurs)? If yes, a visit to the American Museum of Natural History is a great option. If she is into art and artistic artifacts, then The Met is iconic. Do one or the other, not both. 



All of the Holiday windows will be up on the big department stores. Plus there are special holiday markets that will be going (Bryant Park in Midtown has a good one). Also consider splurging on a Broadway show. Sure, the Rockettes are festive but not quite the same as a full Broadway show. 



Central Park is a great way to spend a few hours with a 9 year old unless you have terrible weather. At that time of year you may even have just a bit of color left on the trees.

answers.title:
3.

Re: NYC with 9 year old 11/29-12/1
answers.body: It would help to know the times of your train arrival and departure. You could have almost 3 full days or really only 1 full day and 2 half days, making a big difference in what you can do. Do remember how mobbed the city will be these few days, making everything slower.

posts.title: \nBe prepared for the shock of our disgusting subway system
posts.body:
I want to warn prospective travelers that the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103347094', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC subway system has deteriorated tremendously in recent years. 



Not only are there frequent delays and unpredictable changes because of signal problems, unauthorized activation of brakes, sick or unruly passengers, etc., but both the subway cars and the platforms are often occupied by the homeless with their belongings. Trains sometimes need to be taken out of service because cars have become so filthy from this problem.



It has become so awful, that I usually go out of my way to take longer bus routes rather than to contend with this terrible experience .



I hope visitors will think of using other transpiration options when they can. They should always check MTA.info for the latest delays before venturing out or check out NYCT Subway Twitter



The NYC subway system is an embarrassment
Edited: 14 October 2019, 06:26

answers.title:
1.

Re: Be prepared for the shock of our disgusting subway system
answers.body:
I guess you didn't live here in the 1970s and 1980s. 



Do you have any recommendations for particularly awful stations (or trains) that people should stay away from?

answers.title:
2.

Re: Be prepared for the shock of our disgusting subway system
answers.body:
>>>Trains sometimes need to be taken out of service because (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103347182', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');cars have become so filthy from this problem.<<<



Do you have any evidence for this statement?



I agree that there are many problems with the subway system, but riding in proximity to poor people isn\xe2\x80\x99t one of them. I wish stations were in better repair, especially in the outer boroughs, that they were accessible, and that we had a modern signal system to allow trains to run more frequently (when I was in Mexico City, they seemed to come every 2-3 minutes; here I sometimes have to wait 20 minutes for the R train). But the subway is still the best way to get around most of the city, and I hope visitors won\xe2\x80\x99t be dissuaded by this post.

answers.title:
3.

Re: Be prepared for the shock of our disgusting subway system
answers.body:
I too have read of (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103347312', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');cars being taken out of service BUT this is something that is usually not noticeable. Yes, there are homeless around, but generally you ignore them and they are ignoring! There WAS ( note past tense) an individual who appeared to get his jollys by activating emergency brakes.This happened in the spring and the individual was arrested.



Yes,trains are late but the impact is nil. I have been riding the subway system for over 50 years. I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t tell you even once, in all those years, what time a given train was scheduled to pull into a given station. No one knows or keeps track. People go to the station and get on the next train. Maybe it should have arrived 5 minutes earlier, - got me! Maybe the train that \xe2\x80\x9cshould\xe2\x80\x9d have been there is still 5 minutes away- irrelevant, I\xe2\x80\x99m on a train!



Bottom line I live in Queens and will frequently take the train to Manhattan to see a show. I return to Queens, a lone female. My biggest gripe- even though I\xe2\x80\x99m a senior people rarely offer a seat. I think most feel they need to sit and text or play games on their phone.Harder to do when standing!

4.

Re: Be prepared for the shock of our disgusting subway system
answers.body:
"My biggest gripe- even though I\xe2\x80\x99m a senior people rarely offer a seat. I think most feel they need to sit and text or play games on their phone.Harder to do when standing!"



My parents have told me that people get up for them on the PATH regularly, but never happens on the subway. I am constantly amazed by this.



The tracks are awful from all of the garbage thrown on them. That's not the fault of the MTA, the city, or the state. That's people. We should do better. But I feel the subways are much safer today than they ever were and I ride them more now than I did in all of my years of living in Manhattan. And during the day, they arrive regularly. At night (past 10 or 11), I may wait 20 minutes. I wish that were not so, as they are still crowded.

answers.body:
I moved here from (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103347572', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Boston two years ago and I LOVE the NYC subway. If you want to experience a messed-up subway system, go to Boston where deferred maintenance issues have resulted in incredible delays. A few winters ago, the system came to a grinding halt. It is still a mess and the State has yet to get things squared away. If you search Twitter for #MBTAFail or just #MBTA you will see how fun it is to depend on the trains there. 



As I tell my friends back home\xe2\x80\x94-yes there may be rats on the platform or homeless people sleeping in the cars (or even a hoarder occupying an entire section of the car with stacks of rolled up newspapers), there may be a distressed person screaming profanity at random strangers on the train, it may be \xe2\x80\x9cshowtime\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94-BUT the trains, by and large, run during rush hour. In two years I have experienced two delays and they were minor. 



The biggest issue is the homeless situation, which is a subway issue but much bigger. Homeless people are all over the city and in the subway. Something needs to be done about that. These people need help. Many are mentally ill. No one should have to live like that.

posts.title: \nWheelchair friendly
posts.body:
Hi,







My wife and I are taking her mother on a (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103428150', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');cruise to New York in November to celebrate her 90th birthday. We will be staying in New York for 2 nights [3 days] after the cruise.







Mother needs a wheelchair to get about as she has limited mobility, she can only manage a few stairs as well.







How wheelchair friendly is New York? 







We would want to show her as many of NY's attractions as possible, can you recommend which ones would be accessible to her? Hoe best to see NY in her wheelchair?







Are restaurants wheelchair friendly?











Grateful for any advice

answers.title:
1.

Re: Wheelchair friendly
answers.body:
I took my mum (also uses a wheelchair) to (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103428233', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');New York a couple of years ago. Short of the subway (best avoided) it was a fairly simple (and very enjoyable) experience. Every bus was accessible, and we didn't have any problems hailing a cab. 



All the major attractions were accessible, and no problems at all with any of the restaurants we wanted to visit. 



The subway was a bit messy because, while the 'starting' station might have had a lift/elevator, the destination one might not (or was out of service). That said, the buses were excellent.

answers.title:
2.

Re: Wheelchair friendly
answers.body:
Which attractions?



Most are accessible.

Quite a few are not.

3.

Re: Wheelchair friendly
answers.body: The larger museums are fairly good and may even offer wheelchairs for use within the building. As mentioned, the subway generally is not accessible and the elevators notorious for being broken. Buses, on the other hand, are excellent, but take longer.

answers.title:
4.

Re: Wheelchair friendly
answers.body:
Here is the official city tourist bureau accessibility guide: http://www.nycgo.com/accessibility



SUBWAY - Unfortunately only a few stations have elevators. The stations marked with a wheelchair symbol on the map have elevators: http://web.mta.info/maps/submap.html Be aware that due to retrofitting challenges some stations do not have elevators that serve all platforms (zoom in to the fine print on the map for details) 

Here's info on the accessible stations web.mta.info/accessibility/stations.htm

And you can check here each day for possible elevator outages or repair work: http://advisory.mtanyct.info/EEoutage/

CITY BUSES - While slower, they can be useful - all buses are wheelchair accessible and there is a very extensive route network. Manhattan Bus map: http://web.mta.info/nyct/maps/manbus.pdf 

CABS This is a way to call fully wheelchair accessible cab to you anywhere within the city: http://www.accessibledispatch.com/ (The cost to you is the same as any yellow cab. The cab dispatcher at (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103429268', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');JFK or LGA can also get one, but not at Newark airport in New Jersey.) If she can transfer and you can fold the chair and stash in the trunk a regular cab or car service can also serve.

THEATER - Most Broadway shows offer wheelchair locations (or transfer arm seats), sometimes at a substantial discount for the chair user and a companion seat

Most sidewalks have decent curb cuts and there are only a few locations where there are cobblestone streets or rough sidewalks.

Nearly everyplace will have the ADA (Americans with Disabilities Act) arrangements. A few historical buildings are exempt. Accessible entrances may be adjacent to main entrances - there should be signage with a wheelchair symbol directing you. 

Finding accessible restaurants is not a problem - but be aware and ask about the restroom access which is sometimes not in some of the smaller places

There are a few places that might be on your itinerary you should buy advance tickets for 

-Theater tickets for any "hot" shows (see wheelchair seat info above)

-The Statue Of Liberty / Ellis Island - Ferry & Pedestal Museum are accessible - use only the official ticket seller https://www.statuecruises.com/

- Tenement Museum - only the Shop Life tour is wheelchair accessible, they also do good neighborhood tours https://www.tenement.org/vizinfo_ada.php
Edited: 17 October 2019, 17:55

answers.title:
5.

Re: Wheelchair friendly
answers.body:
P.S. regarding the SOL/Ellis - there is a new freestanding accessible SOL museum that is included in all Statue (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103429762', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Cruises tickets https:/\xe2\x80\xa6 The view from Pedestal terrace requires a few steps. It is unclear at this time what, if anything, remains in the former museum space within the Pedestal

 The Ellis Island museum is also accessible https:/\xe2\x80\xa6physical-mobility.htm

posts.title: \nGetting from JFK to Union Square
posts.body: I am traveling to (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103432217', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC and staying at a hotel within walking distance from Union Square. I was hoping to get some advice on getting from JFK airport to Union Square. My Moovit app is telling me to take the Jamaica LIRR (Far Rockaway ir Hempstead) to East New York, then ride the L to Union Square. I am wondering if anyone has taken this route before and can give me some advice on what to expect. Is there another recommended way to get to Union Square from JFK? I\xe2\x80\x99m not going to be taking taxis to save on costs. Thanks so much!

answers.title:
1.

Re: Getting from JFK to Union Square
answers.body:
Not even close: If you are staying west of (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103432489', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Union Square, like 5th or 6th Avenue, do the following:

Take the JFK Airtrain shuttle that goes to Jamaica. Take the "E" train to "71st avenue-Forest Hills", get off and wait for the "F" train, take it to 14th St (and 6th Avenue), and there your are.

If you are staying near Broadway (Union Square itself) take that same "E" train, get off at "Queens Plaza" instead; wait there for the "R: train and take it to 14th St-Union Square and there you are again.

Total cost will be around $10 per person or less (depending on when the Airtrain fare goes up).



Summary: Airtrain to Jamaica, "E" to Queens Plaza, "R" to Union Square. (a one-hour trip).

One last question: Your hotel may or may not actually be near the stations I mentioned; there are about 5 subway stations within 1/2 mile of Union Square. Where is it really?
Edited: 17 October 2019, 21:34

answers.title:
2.

Re: Getting from JFK to Union Square
answers.body: The way the OP described will actually work, but will be more expensive and probably slower than just taking either of the subway directions in post #1.

answers.title:
3.

Re: Getting from JFK to Union Square
answers.body:
What one has to do when looking up transport directions is look not at what they say if you leave right this mjnute, but what is mentioned over the next hour; then you see a pattern, this (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103432797', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Long Island RR trip occurs every half hour, and is expensive; the huge number of subway ways that leave starting one minute later are a lot more frequent, require fewer transfer, cost less, and take the same amount of time.

They don't even make clear that many Long Island RR train stopping at Jamaica go to East New York, not just the one coming from Far Rockaway, but in the next 30 seconds, that't the one showing up. Any Brooklyn train would be a correct train. But their whole trip is a bad choice.

Take the E train to the R and you will be fine and they both run every 5-8 minutes.

4.

You will probably have to take it up stairs -- 20 to 40 -- because only 20% of the subway stations have elevators or escalators. And the elevators or escalators that do exist are frequently not in service.

posts.title: \nLotte vs warwick
posts.body: I\xe2\x80\x99ve always had the idea of go big or go home. I am taking my mom to nyc for her dream of always wanting to visit at Christmas to see (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103449744', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Rockefeller all lit up and the rockettes . My struggle is which hotel? I like that they are both close to Rockefeller and Christmas activities. My issue is the Lotte is almost $1k more than the Warwick. That extra can go a long ways for food and drinks while we are there, but the Lotte seems so much more luxurious. Does it really make sense to spend the $1k on a room? I appreciate everyone\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts and suggestions!

1.

It all depends on whether or not you can afford to spare that $1K, Only you can determine that,. It will be more of a "Christmas feel" at the Lotte.

If you can still eat where you plan to, shop what you want, and this is a "once in a life time" for your mom..........

Keep in mind that the old structures they use in their promos -- the Villard houses -- are still there and incorporated as part of the hotel only because the hotel's builders (the late ogre Harry Helmsley and his tyrannical ogress wife Leona, a couple locals often put in the same category of repulsiveness as Donald Trump) were forced to save them by the local landmark preservation authorities. Their original intent was to tear them down. But what was built on top of them is awful 1980s Vegas style architecture.



I have never been beyond the ground floor of either hotel, so I cannot comment on the rooms. If your mother wants to be close to Rock Center, the Palace is closer (though the Warwick certainly isn't far), but keep in mind E 50th St. is very crowded at Christmas, and when I walk by the Palace entrance in the evening I often see long lines of people waiting for taxis. Don't know if that would be an issue for you. The Warwick looks fine to me, and I like hotels of that vintage, but have no idea what the rooms are like. Although the area where it is will also be crowded, it's just far enough away from Rock Center to appeal to me, as I hate crowds. But you have to decide based on your and your mother's preferences.

posts.title: \ntypical american dining
posts.body:
hi,were staying at the sheraton hotel in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103467775', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Tribeca in November, 1st time in NY and would like to go out and sample typical local new york dining, breakfast,lunch,dinner somewhere the locals would call into when they are out and about? and when we've done the tourist bit, somewhere nice locally for a drink at night.



 thanks all

Re: typical american dining
answers.body:
You're in a great area for dining. Lots of options within walking distance of your hotel - so a good pick from that perspective. 



The great thing about the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103467871', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');New York City restaurant 'scene' is the chance to eat pretty much anything you'd like, I'd say picking cuisines and types of food that you like would be key. 



Some of my favourites in the area (mind you, I'm merely a tourist and not a local though I tend to focus on food when traveling): 



Breakfast

Square Diner

Tiny's and the Bar Upstairs

Gee Whiz 

Maison Kayser

Tribeca's Kitchen

Sarabeth's



Dinner 



Locanda Verde is great for both breakfast and dinner. 



Frenchette has a good team of chefs / owners. French bistro type of place



Giginio's Trattoria (Italian)

Atera (pricier, 2*, you sit at the counter while they prepare the food, tasting menu)

Tamarind - Indian

The Odeon

Marc Forgione

Khe-Yo

Nish Nush for quick, take away falafel

answers.title:
3.

Re: typical american dining
answers.body:
The thing about "typical" American dining has to be that it's "a-typical." There are so many influences on our cooking, coming from such a diversity of places in the world, that I really don't think you can point to many things that are "typical."

In NYC we love Mexican, Italian, French, Chinese, Japanese, Korean, Greek, Turkish, Indian, and so many other kinds of foods, from so many different regions, it's mind-boggling. 

In the old days you might have said burgers and fries and milkshakes. (Many would be horrified at that suggestion.)

In (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103468098', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');New York, bagels, pastrami on rye, some would say cheesecake. (Personally I hate pastrami and have eaten cheesecake maybe four times in my life.)

Pizza. Spaghetti and other pastas. 

Salmon and scallops, sole and shrimp. 

Salads. All kinds of salads and greens and fruits. Sandwiches. Soup. Ice cream. Cupcakes and cookies.



One of the best things about New York is that you can find cuisine from pretty much anywhere. Go to many neighborhoods and you might as well be in a foreign country.



One of the DEs for New York, Linda E from Brooklyn, has one of the most experienced palates on the Board. She can suggest loads of different types of foods.



You might want to check out a food tour with blogger Ziggy, a regular contributor on the board -- www.eatingwithZiggy.com.

answers.title:
4.

Re: typical american dining
answers.body:
For me, typical American dining is diner food as long as the diner's chef is not based on a cuisine like Greek food (there's a lot of Greek diners.) It's not fine dining but it is what a typical American would go for if they just wanted some good food at a reasonable price.

And Raoul\xe2\x80\x99s, a long time neighborhood staple. And Blue Ribbon Brasserie and The Dutch.

When DH and I go out we very rarely do steak - or even "american" places - much more likely to do Italian, French, indian, chinese, all sorts of other asian places. For drinks, we like the dive bar "Nancy Whiskey", just around the corner. Between Nancy Whiskey and the hotel is one of our favorite Italian restaurants, Pepolino/

answers.title:

Re: typical american dining
answers.body:
Agree\xe2\x80\x94-typical American is usually ethnic food. We are the great melting pot and it\xe2\x80\x99s sushi one day, Italian, Indian food the next, hot pot, Korean, you name it. 



Yes diner food is a staple but even then you\xe2\x80\x99ll find ethnic traces. Yes, lots of Greek owned diners here. Where I grew up in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103471292', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Boston, there were lots of Irish diners. You can find Asian-owned diners here too. They all serve up the same core items of eggs and bacon and pancakes but you\xe2\x80\x99ll often see little hints of who owns the place in some selections. 



If you go to the \xe2\x80\x9cheartland\xe2\x80\x9d of America, you\xe2\x80\x99ll find maybe less spicy \xe2\x80\x9cethnic\xe2\x80\x9d choices than on either coast but even there you\xe2\x80\x99ll see traces of the immigrant groups that settled there. In northern Michigan there\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of German food, for example. 



If you have something specific in mind, you\xe2\x80\x99ll probably find a version of it in NYC. If you want southern US food, look for soul food places up in Harlem. Diner food is everywhere.
