posts.title: \nThanksgiving 2019 in NYC: What to Do & Where to Eat
posts.body:
Thanksgiving is always the fourth Thursday in November. This year it is Thursday, November 28, 2019.



Thanksgiving is one of the biggest holidays in the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103071641', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');United States...it's non-religious and most people celebrate it. As a result, many shops, museums, etc. will be closed, but there's still plenty you can do to fill the day!



First of all, in the morning there is the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade. Here is more information, including a map of parade route and viewing tips:



https://www.macys.com/social/parade/



https://www.nyctourist.com/macys_map.htm



And here is a thread with reports from people on the forum who\xe2\x80\x99ve gone to the parade:



https://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowTopic-g60763\xe2\x80\xa6



On Wednesday evening the 27th (the night before Thanksgiving) the parade's character balloons will be inflated all around the American Museum of Natural History (AMNH). In recent years, the inflation has begun at 1 pm and ended at 8 pm. The entrance to the loop is on Columbus Avenue at 74th Street, and there is a security checkpoint before entering. The loop ends on Central Park West at 81st Street.



Here is a report from a visit to the balloon inflation last year:



https://www.tripadvisor.com.au/ShowTopic-g60\xe2\x80\xa6



Since it\xe2\x80\x99s often asked, here\xe2\x80\x99s a list of hotels with parade view rooms:



https://mommypoppins.com/new-york-city-kids/\xe2\x80\xa6



On Thanksgiving Day, in addition to the parade, some of the other places and things you can do and see include:



Visit one of the observatories (Top of the Rock, Empire State Building, One World) \xe2\x80\x94 Take the Statue Cruises ferry to the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island \xe2\x80\x94 Ride the Staten Island ferry \xe2\x80\x94 See the Radio City Christmas Spectacular (the Rockettes show) \xe2\x80\x94 Walk through Central Park \xe2\x80\x94 Visit the Central Park Zoo \xe2\x80\x94 Walk over the Brooklyn Bridge \xe2\x80\x94 View the Christmas window displays in Midtown (see below for the \xe2\x80\x9cChristmastime in NYC 2019" thread, which includes a walk) \xe2\x80\x94 Wander through neighborhoods with charming architecture (ex: Greenwich Village or Brooklyn Heights)



Here is this year's Christmastime in NYC thread with a list of many of the seasonal attractions:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6103071495



\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2\xe2\x80\xa2



Thanksgiving is a big family holiday focused around the traditional meal of turkey and all the trimmings. Here in NYC it's not uncommon to eat this special meal out, and many restaurants will be serving that day.



Most restaurants only make reservations a month in advance, even for Thanksgiving. Most restaurants take reservations using OpenTable and/or Resy:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6new-york-city-restaurants



https://resy.com/



Here are some lists from last year with Thanksgiving restaurant recommendations:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6best-thanksgiving-restaurants-nyc



grubstreet.com/2018/11/thanksgiving-2018-res\xe2\x80\xa6



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6



https://mommypoppins.com/new-york-city-kids/\xe2\x80\xa6



The new recommendations for 2019 won\xe2\x80\x99t come out until much closer to Thanksgiving, but these are still a good guide!



Enjoy spending Thanksgiving in NYC! :)

answers.title:
1.

Re: Thanksgiving 2019 in NYC: What to Do & Where to Eat
answers.body:
Regarding the recommendation lists linked above:



I think the published lists of recommendations include some really good options, both restaurants that I personally like and restaurants that I know are generally well-regarded. But they also include some places that I myself would never choose...



The lists are a starting point, they help to narrow the field -- choose the places in your price range (and/or in your desired location) and then look up the menus, check out photos to get a feel for the decor/ambience/vibe, look at reviews, etc. It comes down to individual preferences!



I'll also caution that none of our personal recommendations should be taken as "the word". People have different tastes and what one of us loves you may hate. Just like with the restaurants on the lists, you should do your research on the personally recommended restaurants - in the end you have to choose a place that's right for YOU! :)



As a visitor to (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103071678', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC, you might find one of these options particularly festive:



The Rock Center Cafe and its sister restaurant the Sea Grill both look out to the Rockefeller Center ice skating rink. (The tree there will be in position on Thanksgiving Day but will be covered in scaffolding). These two restaurants are already taking reservations, so if you're interested you should book now.



The Bryant Park Grill is directly in Bryant Park, where the holiday market and ice skating rink will already be in full swing on Thanksgiving. (The tree may be up by then, too, although it might not be lit yet). 

The River Cafe in Broolyn will also be serving on Thanksgiving Day - it has panoramic skyline views of Manhattan and a Michelin star. 



Manhatta (in the Financial District) was open on Thanksgiving last year \xe2\x80\x94 on a high floor, beautiful views



The Loeb Boathouse is nestled in the middle of Central Park and has served a special Thanksgiving meal in the past; hopefully this year, too!



Enjoy!

Re: Thanksgiving 2019 in NYC: What to Do & Where to Eat
answers.body:
For 20+ years we were among the 80 makeup artists that paint the faces on the 700-800 clowns that annually walk in the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103076717', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Macy\xe2\x80\x99s parade. (And if you have an aptitude for make-up or art, contact Macy\xe2\x80\x99s for this GREAT opportunity! The artists also have first dibs on being IN the Macy's Parade if additional clowns or balloon handlers are needed.) We churned them out between 5AM - 8 AM at the New Yorker Hotel and at that point they are bussed uptown to the start of the parade. In past years we have either gone to the starting point with them (it is a hoot there standing with the on-lookers and can be crowded, but so is the rest of the route); or we have gone to stand with the camera crews in front of Macy\xe2\x80\x99s to watch the professional acts (many are from Broadway shows). But, ultimately, we found that the best views of the parade, floats, balloons and the professional performers are at home on the couch in front of the TV.



If you are watching the parade along the route, you are likely to miss the professional acts in front of Macy\xe2\x80\x99s. And if you are lucky enough to get a seat or standing room in front of Macy\xe2\x80\x99s, you lose the perspective of the crowds. And in either case, you are likely to be cold and/or wet as it often rains on Thanksgiving Day. The TV gives a superior prospective on the entire event and is much more comfortable.



Bottom line: If you LOVE crowds and MUST have the experience of the parade, then go. We recommend standing along Central Park West a few blocks south (below) of the line-up on the west side of the avenue. Stay away from the Times Square area and the area around Macy\xe2\x80\x99s. It will get VERY crowded in those locations. In any case, start the adventure with an empty bladder!



Otherwise, sleep late and watch the parade on TV with a cup of coffee or tea or hot chocolate.



All that said, if you really want to treat yourself to a great experience the night BEFORE the Parade, go to Central Park West between 77th & 81st Streets to watch the huge balloon cartoon characters being inflated.



CH

answers.title:
4.

Re: Thanksgiving 2019 in NYC: What to Do & Where to Eat
answers.body:
Oh, and for a truly great Thanksgiving meal we highly the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103076741', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Friend of a Farmer restaurant on Irving Place a few blocks south of Gramercy Park (the largest private park in the City). For more information see:



https://www.friendofafarmer.com/menus



CH

answers.title:
5.

Re: Thanksgiving 2019 in NYC: What to Do & Where to Eat
answers.body:
Thanks CH for adding your opinions. I think many visitors do have wonderful experiences at the parade, as evidenced by the link in the opening post where they tell their tales. As long as you research in advance and have a game plan, it can be a lot of fun!



The balloon inflation is around AMNH but it is not on (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103083530', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Central Park West and, to avoid huge crowds, it\xe2\x80\x99s better to go on Wednesday afternoon vs Wednesday evening. The correct information is in my opening post, along with a link to forum DE Anyat\xe2\x80\x99s thread telling of her experience last year. 



Poster LizzieandIzzie also recommends the Thanksgiving meal at Friend of a Farmer, but always cautions to stick with the turkey and avoid the fish. I\xe2\x80\x99ve never been to FOAF on Thanksgiving, but tried their regular menu a few times and was unimpressed. Just my personal opinion, though, and, as I say in my first reply, we all have different tastes!

6.

Re: Thanksgiving 2019 in NYC: What to Do & Where to Eat
answers.body:
Hi again frangi and thank you for another wonderful thread. 



I think your points in Post 1 about finding the restaurant for that all-important Thanksgiving meal are spot-on and so important. It is all about making the choice your own, and what makes giving recommendations so tricky. If you feel like getting the meal right is really important, you need to dig in and do that research.



I found the special Thanksgiving listing on OpenTable a huge help as a starting resource, helping me narrow down budget and style of cuisine and such to begin. A lot of places will publish or have links to their menus there as well.



As for the parade vs. balloon inflation question, I have done both, and would not give up the cold and the crowds of the parade for anything. The balloon inflation was fun (and we had excellent company! \xf0\x9f\x98\x8a) but the parade was mind-blowing excitement. The combined effect of the floats, the marching bands, the anticipation and good cheer of the spectators, and yes, the balloons, made for a thrilling spectacle that I loved being a part of.



My thoughts are if you as a visitor, are so interested to watch a parade that you would turn it on and watch it on TV in your hotel room, and that hotel room is actually in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103103534', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');New York City, why on earth would you not step out your door and see the real thing?? (Of course, not talking about those physically unable, or deathly anxious around crowds, etc.) But my advice, if you are up to it, and if you are debating it, go for it! 



We watched, as CasaHoffa suggests in Post 3, from Central Park West a few blocks south from the start. We had a great vantage point, crowds weren't too bad, and my thoughts were that all the participants would be at their freshest, timing wouldn't be bogged down, and we would be out of there earlier than if we watched further along the route. We also ducked out before the end of the parade and beat the rush out of there. 



Happy planning for you lucky ones! Thanks again for the post, frangi! \xf0\x9f\x98\x80 \xf0\x9f\xa6\x83

posts.title: \nChristmas 2019: Trees-Decorations-Markets-Ice Skating+MORE!
posts.body:
The Christmas season officially starts after Thanksgiving, which in 2019 is on the latest possible date \xe2\x80\x94 Thursday, November 28th. Holiday decorations and displays, including the department store windows and indoor Christmas trees, are typically up up by Thanksgiving Day. Outdoor tree lightings will happen the week after Thanksgiving (the first week of December). Ice skating rinks open in October, and the holiday markets open between between Halloween and early December. Most holiday performances and shows begin in November. 



I have confirmed as many dates as I can below, but not everything has been announced yet. I\xe2\x80\x99ll update the thread as dates become known, plus I\xe2\x80\x99m providing links to websites where dates can be checked. 



Please continue to add to this thread with other Christmastime in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103071474', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC festivities! :)



**CHRISTMAS TREES**



American Museum of Natural History (origami tree) \xe2\x80\x93 Monday, November 25th through Sunday, January 12, 2020



Metropolitan Museum of Art (baroque tree) \xe2\x80\x93 Tuesday, November 26th through Sunday, January 5, 2020 



Lincoln Center \xe2\x80\x93 a tree lighting kicks off the Winter\xe2\x80\x99s Eve celebration on the evening of Monday, December 2nd, and then the tree remains lit for the holiday season:



http://www.winterseve.nyc



Rockefeller Center \xe2\x80\x93 the tree lighting ceremony is on Wednesday, December 4th; the tree will remain lit daily from 5:30 am to 11:30 pm into early January \xe2\x80\x94 no end date given yet, keep checking the website:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6



Bryant Park - the tree lighting \xe2\x80\x9cskate-tacular\xe2\x80\x9d should be in the first week of December, and then the tree remains lit for the holiday season. No date has been confirmed yet, keep checking the website:



bryantpark.org/programs/tree-lighting-skate-\xe2\x80\xa6



There will be outdoor Christmas trees in Madison Square Park, Gramercy Park, and Washington Square Park. The tree lighting ceremonies are usually in early December (TBA), but the trees are sometimes lit up even before the ceremony.



There are also nice Christmas trees in the lobby of the main branch of the New York Public Library, in the lobby of the Plaza Hotel, and in the courtyard of the Palace Hotel



**HOLIDAY WINDOWS AND DISPLAYS**



The 2019 dates for the windows have not yet been confirmed; I will update the thread as they are announced. All should be unveiled by Thanksgiving Day. 



In addition to the department store window displays, lots of shops and buildings are beautifully decorated inside and out, both in Midtown and in more residential neighborhoods. Almost all of the decorations are up by Thanksgiving weekend.



There is a light show on the outside of Saks Fifth Avenue, directly across from Rockefeller Center. First show starts at 4:35 pm, last show is at 11:35 pm, shows start every 10 minutes.



The UNICEF crystal snowflake hangs over the intersection of 5th Avenue and 57th Street.



The Helmsley Building lights up for the holiday season - it sits in the middle of Park Avenue at 46th Street, and the trees in the Park Avenue median for several blocks up from the Helmsley Building are wrapped in Christmas lights.



There is an impressive display of large LED stars in the atrium of the Time Warner Center every year; they pulsate and change colors. 



**HOLIDAY WALK**



My favorite walk through Midtown at Christmastime:



-- Start with the holiday windows at Macy\xe2\x80\x99s, then walk five blocks up Sixth Avenue to Bryant Park 

-- Stroll the holiday market, get a hot drink and a snack, and sit and watch the ice skaters under the tree

-- Walk over to Fifth Avenue and pop into the lobby of the New York Public Library (at 41st Street) to see the lovely Christmas tree. The lions in front of the NYPL building will also be wearing their holiday wreaths 

-- Keep walking up Fifth Avenue to Rockefeller Center (between 49th and 50th Streets). See the decorations along the Rockefeller Center promenade and look at the tree and ice skating rink 

-- Watch the light show on the front of Saks Fifth Avenue, then cross Fifth Avenue and look at the Saks holiday windows

-- Keep waking up Fifth Avenue to 60th Street, crossing back and forth and enjoying the decorations along the way - these include Cartier, Henri Bendel, Tiffany\xe2\x80\x99s the Unicief snowflake, and Bergdorf Goodman

-- Turn right onto 60th Street and walk over to Madison Avenue. View the holiday windows at Barney\xe2\x80\x99s (between 60th and 61st Streets)

-- Head east to Lexington Avenue and view the holiday windows at Bloomingdale\xe2\x80\x99s (between 59th and 60th Street)



This walk is best done in the dark, starting no earlier than ~4:30 pm. It\xe2\x80\x99s less crowded if you can go on Monday-Thursday evening. Note the closing time of the NYPL, which can be between 5 pm and 8 pm depending on the day. 



**HOLIDAY MARKETS**



Bryant Park \xe2\x80\x93 Thursday, October 31st through Sunday, January 5, 2020



Grand Central Terminal \xe2\x80\x93 Monday, November 18th through Tuesday, December 24th



Union Square \xe2\x80\x93 Thursday, November 21st through Tuesday, December 24th 



Columbus Circle \xe2\x80\x93 Wednesday, December 4th through Tuesday, December 24th 



**ICE SKATING RINKS**



Rockefeller Center \xe2\x80\x93 Saturday, October 12th through to April 2020



Wollman Rink in Central Park \xe2\x80\x93 Monday, October 21st through Sunday, April 5, 2020



The Rink at Bryant Park \xe2\x80\x93 Thursday, October 31st through to March 2020



**HOLIDAY PERFORMANCES**



The Rocketttes perform the Christmas Spectacular at Radio City Music Hall from Friday, November 8th through Sunday, January 5, 2020:



https://www.rockettes.com/christmas/



The NYC Ballet performs the Nutcracker at Lincoln Center from Friday, November 29th through Sunday, January 5, 2020:



https://www.nycballet.com/ballets/n/george-b\xe2\x80\xa6



The New York Philharmonic at Lincoln Center will conduct holiday concerts in December:



https://nyphil.org/calendar\xe2\x80\xa6



There will be holiday concerts at Carnegie Hall as well:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6calendar



Many churches have Christmas concerts; here are a few of the better-known ones:



http://www.saintthomaschurch.org



https://www.trinitywallstreet.org



https://www.saintpatrickscathedral.org



http://www.stjohndivine.org



**OTHER**



Santa will be at Macy\xe2\x80\x99s Herald Square from Friday, November 29th through Monday, December 24th \xe2\x80\x94 advance reservations are required:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6thank-you



The Holiday Train Show at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx runs from Saturday, November 23rd through Sunday, January 26, 2020:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6



Forum feedback on the Christmas themed cruises (cocoa & carols, holiday jazz, etc) on Classic Harbor Line has been positive:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6



The residential neighborhood of DYKER HEIGHTS in Brooklyn is known for its amazing Christmas lights and displays. This bus tour of the Dyker Heights lights has been positively reviewed on the forum:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6



Free Tours By Foot also offers a Dyker Heights lights tour, plus the site give information for a self-guided tour:

freetoursbyfoot.com/dyker-heights-christmas-\xe2\x80\xa6



**CHRISTMAS EVE CAROLING**



Washington Square Park \xe2\x80\x93 5 pm on Tuesday, December 24th 



Gramercy Park \xe2\x80\x93 6 pm on Tuesday, December 24th 



Enjoy the festive season in NYC!

1.

posts.title: \nGetting from Union Square to Newark Airport
posts.body: I am traveling to (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103437114', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC soon and will be flying out of Newark airport on my return trip. What is the best way (least transfers and economical) to get from Union Square -14th station to Newark airport? I am staying at Moxy NYC (112 East 11th street) and figured that I\xe2\x80\x99d start by walking to Union Square. What recommendations can you make for getting to Newark airport, terminal C from Union Square? I am open to taking a cab or uber to another station, as well.

answers.title:
1.

Re: Getting from Union Square to Newark Airport
answers.body:
All you do is take the uptown Q, N, W, or R train (your old friend) to 34th St, go out in to the street, walk from 6th Avenue to 7th Avenue, go down into (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103437438', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Penn Station and take a New Jersey Transit Commuter Train (no relation to the subway, it's a separate regular railroad system) to the EWR (Newark Airport) Station. The ticket costs about $13.00 Then you use your ticket to get on the EWR Airtrain right to your terminal. 

As easy as JFK, just that you have to walk one avenue (1/7 mile) in the street. And again, if lucky elevators all the way.

https://www.njtransit.com/rg/rg_servlet.srv\xe2\x80\xa6

If it's raining, do this: Take the same Uptown Q, N, R, or W to 42nd St, follow the red signs to the Downtown 1,2, or 3 train (all on the same same platform) take one of those one stop to 34th St, and you are under Penn Station right there. Then go to NJ Transit without exiting the building.

2.

Re: Getting from Union Square to Newark Airport
answers.body: You have been so incredibly helpful! Thank you a million for sharing these details! I think I\xe2\x80\x99ll be an expert at taking trains and subways by the time this trip is over! :-)

answers.title:
3.

Re: Getting from Union Square to Newark Airport
answers.body: North of DC is 100% right. I take this all the time. Great directions.

answers.title:

Re: Getting from Union Square to Newark Airport
answers.body:
my way is different. As I explained in my post for your arrival, I\xe2\x80\x99m okay with a little walking through the leafy loveliness of (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103446768', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Greenwich Village side streets and prefer that over dragging luggage up and down stairs through crowded stations and trains.



I walk over to the PATH station on 9th Street and 6th Avenue, take the PATH (more like a subway) to Journal Square, make the very easy transfer to another PATH line to Newak/Penn Station and then get on the train to the airport that others describe.



If you decide to take the subway up to Penn Station in NYC, be aware that station is giant with several separate railways.it can be hard to find your way around.

answers.title:
5.

Re: Getting from Union Square to Newark Airport
answers.body:
Yes, (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103448596', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Penn Station is large, yes it is tedious to walk through it, but the signs are clear. You only need to follow one sign: "NJ Transit --->". That's as difficult as it gets. When you get to the main NJ/Amtrak Mezzanine, you look for then next NJ Transit train on the list leaving with the letters "EWR". That's the train you want.

The other way is certainly an good option; and it is a nice walk, but it's two somewhat slower trains, and you still have to get the NJ Transit train in Newark (much easier to change, however) But you only take the NJT train one stop to EWR. Speaking as a train lover, the PATH is one of my absolute favorites, and I've been all over N. America and Europe on many subway/light rail lines, So for variety, and a pleasant walk, do the PATH thing IF you want to.

posts.title: \nItinerary Help
posts.body:
My family and I are visiting (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103459843', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC Nov 17th-20th. We are staying at the Luma hotel. 

I have put together some what of an itinerary, but since my dad will be traveling with a mobility scooter, I tried not to cram too much in, as I am not sure how easy he will be able to get around the city with it. Any help would be much appreciated. 



Day 1 Sunday Nov 17

Arrive to LGA at 11am (get to hotel around 1) 

3:30pm boat tour (90min)

dinner

Macy's 



Day 2 Monday Nov 18

7:30am NBC studios / Today show

St Patrick's Cathedral

Top of the Rock

Saks Fifth Ave 

Explore Times Square 



Day 3 Tuesday Nov 19

Central Park (will spend at least half a day )



Day 4 Wednesday Nov 20

9/11 Memorial 

Brooklyn Bridge

Depart 8pm



Should I purchase TOTR tickets in advance? not sure what time it gets dark or best time for a view.

I did not add any shows since no one in the party was interested.

Also plan on walking short distances and taking cabs on the longer trips.

answers.title:
1.

Re: Itinerary Help
answers.body:
This seems doable, but I hope you have Plan B for



A) you may not be able to check in to your hotel until 3 or 4 unless you arrange an early check in, which might require a fee



B) you have lots of outdoor time ( (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103460971', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Central Park, Memorial, Brdge). What happens if it is cold or raining?



You can google sunset time for any date.
Edited: yesterday, 15:00

answers.title:
2.

Re: Itinerary Help
answers.body:
I think you really need to spend some time thinking about some indoor activities, for Plan B's. It's already been pretty cold -- scarf, hat and glove weather for some people. 



If I were you I would change the boat tour to to the next day. It's always not a great idea to plan something expensive and/or timed, on arrival day. Anything can go wrong. (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103464208', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Plane can be late/cancelled, luggage lost, room reservation messed up, etc.



Half a day in Central Park -- it's probably going to be too cold to do that. I would break it up with a visit to the Metropolitan Museum or the American Museum of Natural History, or the New York Historical Society.

answers.title:
3.

Re: Itinerary Help
answers.body: Sunset will be about 4:30 if I did my research correctly. Normally, we don't recommend buying any observatory ticket very far in advance as weather can adversely affect the view. However, sunset visits to observatories are very popular so you will want to monitor ticket availability to ensure tickets don't see out before you buy.
